definition:
Axial vector behaves like a vector (polar vector) except that it is
invariant under the inversion of its coordinate axes. For example, the
cross product of two vectors $\bold{A}$ and $\bold{B}$,
$$\bold{A}\times\bold{B}$$ is an axial vector. The cross product of two
axial vectors stays as an axial vector, whereas the cross product of an
axial vector and a polar vector turns to be a polar vector.
